factoid: The mummers were some of the house serfs.
The mummers dressed up as bears.
The mummers dressed up as Turks.
The mummers dressed up as innkeepers.
The mummers dressed up as ladies.
The mummers were frightening and funny.
The mummers brought with them cold from outside.
The mummers brought with them a feeling of gaiety.
The mummers crowded into the anteroom at first timidly.
The mummers pushed into the ballroom.
The mummers were shy at first in the ballroom.
The mummers were more and more merrily and heartily in the ballroom.
The mummers started singing.
The mummers started dancing.
The mummers started playing Christmas games.
The countess identified the mummers.
The countess laughed at the mummers' costumes.
The countess went into the drawing room.
The count sat in the ballroom.
The count was smiling radiantly.
The count applauded the players.
The young people disappeared.
An old lady in a hooped skirt appeared among the mummers in the ballroom.
The old lady in a hooped skirt was Nicholas.
A Turkish girl among the mummers was Pétya.
A clown among the mummers was Dimmler.
A hussar among the mummers was Natásha.
A Circassian among the mummers was Sónya.
Sónya had a burnt-cork mustache.
Sónya had eyebrows.
Those who were not dressed up gave condescending surprise, nonrecognition, and praise.
The young people decided their costumes were so good that they ought to be shown elsewhere.
The roads were in splendid condition.
Nicholas wanted to take everyone for a drive in his troyka.
Nicholas proposed to take about a dozen serf mummers.
Nicholas proposed to drive to "Uncle's".
The countess said "No, why disturb the old fellow?"
The countess said "Besides, you wouldn’t have room to turn round there."
The countess said "If you must go, go to the Melyukóvs'".
Melyukóva was a widow.
Melyukóva lived three miles from the Rostóvs.
Melyukóva had a family.
Melyukóva had tutors.
Melyukóva had governesses.
The old count chimed "That's right, my dear."
The old count was thoroughly aroused.
The old count said he would dress up at once and go with them.
The old count said he would make Pashette open her eyes.
The countess would not agree to the old count going.
The old count had had a bad leg all these last days.
It was decided the old count must not go.
It was decided if Louisa Ivánovna would go with them, the young ladies might go to the Melyukóvs'.
Louisa Ivánovna was Madame Schoss.
Sónya was generally timid and shy.
Sónya’s costume was the best of all.
Sónya had a mustache.
Sónya had eyebrows.
Everyone told Sónya she looked very handsome.
Sónya was in a spirited and energetic mood.
Sónya had an inner voice telling her that now or never her fate would be decided.
In her male attire, Sónya seemed quite a different person.
Louisa Ivánovna consented to go.
Four troyka sleighs with large and small bells drove up to the porch in half an hour.
The troyka sleighs had runners squeaking and whistling over the frozen snow.
Natásha was foremost in setting a merry holiday tone.
The merry holiday tone grew stronger as it passed from one to another.
The merry holiday tone reached its climax when they all came out into the frost.
They all got into the sleighs.
They were talking, calling to one another, laughing, and shouting.
Two of the troykas were the usual household sleighs.
The third troyka was the old count's.
The old count's troyka had a trotter from the Orlóv stud as shaft horse.
The fourth troyka was Nicholas' own.
Nicholas' troyka had a short shaggy black shaft horse.
Nicholas wore an old lady's dress.
Nicholas belted his hussar overcoat over the dress.
Nicholas stood in the middle of the sleigh.
Nicholas had reins in hand.
The sleigh was so light that Nicholas could see the moonlight reflected from the metal harness disks.
The sleigh was so light that Nicholas could see the moonlight reflected from the eyes of the horses.
The horses looked round in alarm at the noisy party under the shadow of the porch roof.
Natásha got into Nicholas' sleigh.
Sónya got into Nicholas' sleigh.
Madame Schoss got into Nicholas' sleigh.
Two maids got into Nicholas' sleigh.
Dimmler got into the old count's sleigh.
Dimmler's wife got into the old count's sleigh.
Pétya got into the old count's sleigh.
The rest of the mummers seated themselves in the other two sleighs.
Nicholas shouted "You go ahead, Zakhár!" to his father's coachman.
Nicholas wished for a chance to race past his father's coachman.
The old count's troyka started forward.
The old count's troyka squeaked on its runners as though freezing to the snow.
The old count's troyka's deep-toned bell clanged.
The side horses pressed against the shafts of the middle horse.
The side horses sank in the snow.
The snow was dry and glittered like sugar.
The side horses threw the snow up.
